attributes.title: PRE-ANALYSIS PLAN for 12 Reanalyses of TESS Studies

q1.value: PRE-ANALYSIS PLAN for 12 Reanalyses of TESS Studies

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study will reanalyze 12 experiments conducted through the Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences (TESS) platform to serve as an out-of-sample test of the “Persuasion in Parallel” hypothesis that subjects, by and large, respond to information treatments by updating in the direction of information regardless of background attributes.

q16.value: This study will reanalyze 12 experiments conducted through the Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences (TESS) platform to serve as an out-of-sample test of the “Persuasion in Parallel” hypothesis that subjects, by and large, respond to information treatments by updating in the direction of information regardless of background attributes.

q17.value: The main analysis will consist in estimating the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) of each treatment, conditional on respondent partisanship. Our expectation is that treatment effects will be in the same direction and of approximately the same magnitude for Republicans and Democrats.

attributes.title: Examining Policing in Uganda: A List and Endorsement Experiment

q1.value: Examining Policing in Uganda: A List and Endorsement Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Existing studies have explored whether ethnicity affects cooperation and conflict. Yet prior research has not explored the politics of policing. Specifically, the literature on ethnicity and conflict has not shown whether ethnicity affects the willingness of civilians to cooperate with the police. This study seeks to answer this question by employing a list experiment and an endorsement experiment in a nationally representative survey of Uganda. The list experiment tests whether the lack of ethnic representation in the police force decreases whether people report crimes to the police. The endorsement experiment varies whether a recent initiative (Mayumba Kumi) is endorsed by the Ugandan Police Force or local politicians. Mayumba Kumi is an initiative to provide neighborhood watches to increase information provisions to the police. The endorsement experiment tests the effects of support by a local politician compared to the Uganda Police Force on respondents' support for the initiative. By exploring the politics of policing in a multiethnic autocracy, this study contributes to a growing literature on policing, repression, and ethnic politics.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Perceptions of under-representation in the police force decreases the willingness of individuals to cooperate with the police. Hypothesis 2: Endorsement for community policing initiatives by local politicians increases civilian support. Hypothesis 3: Endorsement for community policing initiatives by the National Police Force increases civilian cooperation in regions ethnically aligned with the incumbent but decreases support in regions ethnically aligned with opposition leaders.

q17.value: List experiment test hypothesis 1 and the remaining hypotheses are tested with an endorsement experiment.

q24.value: Mildway Uganda Research Ethics Committee (#REC REF 0204-2017); Uganda National Council of Science and Technology (REF SS4302); IRB (IRB00104491)

attributes.title: The Effect of Factual Information on Candidate Evaluations

q1.value: The Effect of Factual Information on Candidate Evaluations

q2.value: Leonardo Arriola | K. Ochieng' Opalo | Donghyun Danny Choi | Matthew K. Gichohi

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Devolution of political authority is a trend increasingly seen across Africa. This decentralization of state activity to lower levels of government not only affects the delivery of public services, but also the relationships between citizens and their representatives. In a decentralized system, voting decisions are no longer restricted to the selection of national representatives; voters must also assess the performance of elected officials across multiple levels of government. Decentralized democracy thus places new cognitive demands on voters in ways not yet fully understood by scholars of democratization in Africa and the developing world. Focusing on the devolved system of governance in Kenya, we examine a set of questions aimed at unpacking the citizen-representative relationship in decentralizing polities: How do voters living in decentralized political systems interpret information about government performance? How do they assign credit or blame when their local and national governments often share joint responsibility for providing basic public services? To gain leverage on these questions, we employ an experimental survey design aimed at establishing the causal effect of a voter's ethnic relationship with politicians (coethnic vs. non-coethnic), partisan identity (co-partisan vs. non-copartisan), and information access (county budget expenditures) on performance evaluations and responsibility attributions.

q16.value: Our main hypotheses are that: (1) voters will evaluate candidate performance based in line with the type of information received (positive or negative); (2) voter evaluations of candidates will be influenced by the ease with which they are able to attribute responsibility to them for the level of development in their area; and (3) voters’ evaluations of candidates will either be discounted or bolstered depending on ethnic and partisan alignment. The main outcomes of interest in our study are the self-reported voting preferences of voters and the self-reported evaluation of the performance of politicians.

q17.value: To measure the effect of information and co-partisanship on voter’s candidate evaluations and voting behavior under devolved government, we present randomly selected subjects living in Trans-Nzoia or Uasin Gishu — two counties in Kenya — with a three-minute video clip in either English or Swahili. Participation is limited to those of voting age. The video clip presents experimental subjects with accurate information regarding the use of public funds in their county and the incumbent governor seeking re-election during the 2017 electoral cycle. The experimental manipulation involves varying the information embedded in the video regarding: (a) how funds are allocated (a formula or political negotiation); (b) whether allocated development funds meet legal thresholds (good news) or development spending cannot be accounted for (bad news); and (c) whether the county’s incumbent governor is aligned with the incumbent president or the opposition presidential candidate. The experimental design employed is a 2 x 2 x 2 factorial design with a total of 8 treatment conditions. Assignment to treatment group is random and with equal probability.

attributes.title: Do welcome streams matter? Testing a ladder of engagement in political fundraising.

q1.value: Do welcome streams matter? Testing a ladder of engagement in political fundraising.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Many political fundraising lists use a "welcome stream" to onboard new email signups into the regular fundraising stream. The goal of a welcome stream is to ease new list subscriber into the mostly fundraising heavy email content while trying to activate new subscribers by sending engaging content. This experiment uses a live political fundraising database to test the value of asking list subscribers to take an action before making a donation. The test has research value as very few experiments in academic literature exist with live fundraising data. The experiment is also useful for practitioners looking for concrete data on the efficacy of email list management tactics.

q16.value: H1a, b, c: Being asked to take an action before receiving a fundraising appeal will increase a) the probability of making a contribution; b) the amount contributed and c) decrease unsubscribe rates. RQ1a,b, c: Does the effect being asked to take an action increase a) the probability of making a contribution and b) the amount contributed differ for prior donors and non-donors? Does the effect of being asked to take an action c) decrease unsubscribe rates?

q17.value: (response updated on March 15, 2018) People who have opted-in to an email contact list are randomly assigned to one of three conditions (blocking on whether the individual was a prior donor): Group 1 (welcome + call to action): Gets intro email w/ no call to action. Gets follow-up fundraising email. Group 2 (welcome only): Gets intro email w/ call to take action. Gets follow up fundraising email. Group 3 (control): Gets no intro email. Gets fundraising email. We will initially use t-tests to compare four outcomes across the three groups: an indicator for donating or not, natural log of (1 + total donations in dollars), total donations in dollars, and an indicator for unsubscribing (1=unsubscribe, 0=not). We plan to use linear regression to estimate the average treatment effect on three outcomes: (an indicator for donating or not), natural log of (1 + total donations), total donations in dollars, and an indicator for unsubscribing (1=unsubscribe, 0=not) for the time period in question. We will run regressions with separate indicators for the call to action group (equals 1 for group 1, 0 otherwise) and those who receive only the welcome stream with no call to action (equals 1 for group 2, 0 otherwise). The coefficients for each of these indicators will represent the average treatment effect relative to the control group. We will compare the coefficients of each of these groups to evaluate whether the call to action has a larger effect than the welcome stream alone. Regressions will include an indicator for prior donation, and fixed effects for zip code. Clustered standard errors will be estimated for coefficients. We will also conduct regressions with an interaction term for prior donation X treatment to explore whether the appeal had a different impact on people who contributed in the past.

registration_responses.q1: Do welcome streams matter? Testing a ladder of engagement in political fundraising.

attributes.title: Prisoners of the Past? Historical Narratives as Heuristics in International Cooperation

q1.value: Prisoners of the Past? Historical Narratives as Heuristics in International Cooperation

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study explores if historical narratives of victimhood negatively affect a country’s propensity to engage in international cooperation, by fostering the impression that other countries are not to be trusted. It builds on the combined research of conflict studies as well as behavioral and social psychology, suggesting that a group’s sense of victimhood reduces general trust toward former perpetrators, perceived or real, and third persons alike. This is likely because narratives function as “availability heuristics,” emphasizing in one’s mind past events that fit the plot, while deemphasizing events that do not. Narratives about the past thereby skew one’s sense of what happened and, therefore, what is likely to happen next. What has received less attention in these literatures, and what will be the focus of this present project, is a) how and to what extent precisely narratives exert a causal effect on decision-making and b) how these narratives shape general (dis)trust toward the international community. The proposed study applies research on the behavioral effect of narratives to questions of international cooperation.

q16.value: The experiments test the hypothesis that exposure to historical narratives of victimhood reduces people’s willingness to engage in international cooperation. This main outcome variable, international cooperation, is measured through stated preferences regarding a) the extension of concessions to other countries (reciprocity) and b) contributions to international public goods. To measure the subjects’ willingness to extend concessions, the project uses a vignette that asks subjects to imagine themselves in a negotiation situation and to consider the level of concessions that they are willing to extend to other EU governments. The language of the original vignette was simplified in order to ease this task for citizens with less EU knowledge. The questions measuring the subjects’ willingness to contribute to EU public goods were adapted from the EUpinions survey to allow for a potential comparison of effects.

q17.value: We devise a between-subjects survey experiment in which each subject is randomly assigned to one of three conditions. Each condition involves a brief essay tasks in which participants are asked to reflect on various situations in the history of their country. In order to invoke in the subjects’ minds latent historical narratives, the treatment condition, respondents are asked to reflect on situations in which their country was treated badly by others. The project establishes an empirically derived baseline that approximates the subjects’ preferences in the absence of a treatment effect. For that purpose, subjects are randomly assigned to two additional conditions where they are primed to access either a countervailing narrative or a mix of both.

q23.value: To be filed with the LSE ethics committee

attributes.title: Changing Political Identities and Campaign Activism

q1.value: Changing Political Identities and Campaign Activism

q2.value: Katharina Lawall | Stuart Turnbull-Dugarte | Joshua Townsley | Florian Foos

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Recent work has begun to establish a consensus regarding the growing importance of Brexit-based identities (Hobolt, Leeper and Tilley, 2018). Whilst UK voters have traditionally structured their political beliefs around party loyalties, partisan identities have become increasingly replaced by voters’ political attitudes towards Brexit. This involves a transformation of the dimensional space of British politics away from left-right party competition within a multi-party system towards a dichotomous identification as either a Remainer or a Brexiteer. In other words, it matters less whether one is a Labour voter or a Liberal Democrat voter, and more where one stands on the most salient political debate of the day: Brexit. The displacement of partisan identities by those structured around voter views on Brexit present parties with a dilemma. Given that partisan cues have traditionally played a major role in the UK in shaping political preferences and electoral behaviour, the emergence of new Brexit-based identities disrupts the status quo. In such circumstances, when parties seek to mobilise and activate their supporters to take political action, should they emphasize these new identities in order to maximise supporter mobilisation? Furthermore, while many theories of political behaviour have traditionally focused on positive in-group attachments as foundations for political identities, there has recently been a renewed interest in negative partisanship, a strong dislike of political parties and groups. These strong negative feelings towards political parties and their supporters have been on the rise (Iyengar et al. 2019) and have important implications for behaviour inside and outside of politics (Abramowitz and Webster 2016). In the UK, Leavers and Remainers harbour strong negative feelings towards individuals “from the other side”, describing them on average as less honest and intelligent (Hobolt, Leeper and Tilley, 2018). How do such strong negative feelings affect political activism, and do they have stronger mobilising effects than positive identities?

q16.value: Research Question i) Are Brexit-based identity cues more effective at encouraging supporters to donate or to volunteer for a political party than partisan-based identity cues? ii) Are negative partisanship cues more effective than positive cues at encouraging voters to donate or to volunteer for a political party? iii) Are negative partisanship cues more effective when combined with Brexit-based identity cues than with partisan-based identity cues? iv) Are two asks to donate and to volunteer supplementary or complimentary at encouraging supporters to volunteer their money and time? Hypotheses H1 (baseline): Email contact from the party will mobilise its supporters to donate to the campaign/to volunteer. H2 (Brexit identity thesis): Messages that prime Brexit-based identities will be more effective at encouraging volunteering/campaign donations than messages that prime traditional party identities. H3 (Negative partisanship thesis): Messages that prime negative partisan cues will be more effective than messages that prime positive partisan cues. H4 (Interaction hypothesis): Messages that prime negative partisan cues will be more effective when combined with Brexit-based identities rather than traditional party identities. H5 (substitution hypothesis): Messages that include two asks will influence supporters to substitute time for donations.

q17.value: Random Assignment of Treatment Using complete random assignment, subjects will be assigned to thirteen groups: Control (.2), and Treatments T1, T2, T3, T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9, T10, T11 and T12. To avoid ordering effects, we assign T5-T8 (with p=.05) to receive the additional volunteer ask after the donation ask, and assign T9-T12 (with p=.05) to receive the volunteer ask before the donation ask. Treatment C: Individuals assigned to C will receive no email from the party. T1: Individuals assigned to T1 will receive an email asking them to donate to the party in the lead up to a general election campaign. The T1 email will prompt party members with a number of positive partisan cues towards the Liberal Democrats. T2: Individuals assigned to T2 will receive an email asking them to donate to the party in the lead up to a general election campaign. The T2 email will prompt party members with a number of negative partisan cues against the Conservatives. T3: Individuals assigned to T3 will receive an email asking them to donate to the party in the lead up to a general election campaign. The T3 email will prompt party members with a number of positive cues based on their identity as Remainers. T4: Individuals assigned to T3 will receive an email asking them to donate to the party in the lead up to a general election campaign. The T4 email will prompt party members with a number of negative cues based on their opposition to Leave/Leavers. T5-T8: Repeat treatment messages of T1-T4 respectively with addition of ask in the form of volunteering. The donation ask comes before the volunteering ask. T9-T12: Repeat treatment messages of T1-T4 respectively with addition of ask in the form of volunteering. The volunteering ask comes before the donation ask.

q19.value: Experimental subjects are pre-identified members of the UK Liberal Democrat party with a valid email address. The total sample consists of 98,206 individuals.

attributes.title: Do Violations of International Law Increase Support for Insurgents? A Quasi-Natural Experiment in Mosul

q1.value: Do Violations of International Law Increase Support for Insurgents? A Quasi-Natural Experiment in Mosul

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Do violations of international humanitarian law (IHL) increase civilian support for insurgencies? A quasi-natural experiment arising from the geography of Mosul, an Iraqi city that was governed by the Islamic State (IS) for more than three years until its recapture by Iraqi forces in 2017, presents a unique opportunity to answer this question. Since Mosul is divided by the Tigris River, the battle to retake the city from IS unfolded in two stages. The exposure of otherwise similar East and West Mosul neighborhoods to different levels of collateral damage as a result of plausibly exogenous changes in military tactics and personnel between the two operations enables an empirical test of the hypothesis that violations of IHL increase civilian support for insurgents as measured through a survey of a random sample of 1,400 residents of Mosul. We assess whether Mosul residents whose households experienced higher levels of collateral damage during the battle for Mosul (as measured through self-reported incidents of death, injury, and property destruction and through satellite imagery) are more likely to express support for IS than those who experienced lower levels of collateral damage.

q27.value: IIACSS (Independent Institute for Administration and Civil Society Studies)

registration_responses.q1: Do Violations of International Law Increase Support for Insurgents? A Quasi-Natural Experiment in Mosul
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes
registration_responses.q15: Do violations of international humanitarian law (IHL) increase civilian support for insurgencies? A quasi-natural experiment arising from the geography of Mosul, an Iraqi city that was governed by the Islamic State (IS) for more than three years until its recapture by Iraqi forces in 2017, presents a unique opportunity to answer this question. Since Mosul is divided by the Tigris River, the battle to retake the city from IS unfolded in two stages. The exposure of otherwise similar East and West Mosul neighborhoods to different levels of collateral damage as a result of plausibly exogenous changes in military tactics and personnel between the two operations enables an empirical test of the hypothesis that violations of IHL increase civilian support for insurgents as measured through a survey of a random sample of 1,400 residents of Mosul. We assess whether Mosul residents whose households experienced higher levels of collateral damage during the battle for Mosul (as measured through self-reported incidents of death, injury, and property destruction and through satellite imagery) are more likely to express support for IS than those who experienced lower levels of collateral damage.
registration_responses.q27: IIACSS (Independent Institute for Administration and Civil Society Studies)

attributes.title: Willingness to Pay for Micro-Solar Power: Experimental Evidence

q1.value: Willingness to Pay for Micro-Solar Power: Experimental Evidence

q2.value: Jason Chun Yu Wong | Brian Blankenship | S.P. Harish | Johannes Urpelainen

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: There is growing evidence that electricity consumption and measures of economic development are positively correlated, where electricity access and use bring about socioeconomic benefits (Ah- mad et al., 2014; Chakravorty et al., 2014; Lee et al., 2017; Aklin et al., 2017). A research priority in the field of energy consumption and development is to develop further empirical estimates using rigorous, experimental methods, such as randomized control trial studies (Lee et al., 2017). In rural India, many households continue to use kerosene for lighting needs. Kerosene as the energy source for lighting is associated with a significant fiscal burden for subsidies, significant health effects, and fire and mortality risk (Chaurey and Kandpal, 2009). In contrast, the solar lantern is a practical replacement that overcomes some of these risks. Increasing implementation of solar lanterns began as early as 1991, but uptake and dissemination had been very low, despite documented returns to technology adoption, such as in the case of the cookstove (Chaurey and Kandpal, 2009; Bensch et al., 2015). Recent studies documented that using solar lanterns bring about at least limited health benefits in the short term, such as relief of eye irritation (Kudo et al., 2018). In this study, we design and implement an experiment using the Becker-Degroot-Marschak (BDM) method (Becker et al., 1964) to solicit household’s willingness to pay (WTP) for micro-solar power in the form of a solar lantern. The experiment has three treatment arms (Cash Transfer, Vouchers, Microfinance), which are intended to study the potential impacts of three incentive schemes on household’s WTP for solar lanterns. We conduct the experiment in 500 households in Uttar Pradesh.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 (Incentive Treatment, WTP for Solar Lantern). The incentive treatments increase the household WTP for the solar lantern. Hypothesis 2 (Between Treatment Effectiveness). Of the three treatment arms, the Vouchers treatment is the most effective in increasing household WTP for a solar lantern. This is followed by the Cash Transfer treatment, with the Microfinance treatment being the least effective. Hypothesis 3 (Income and Treatment). Higher income households receiving the treatments should have higher WTP for solar lanterns. Hypothesis 4 (Lighting Importance). The treatments will increase WTP for a solar lantern more among people who see adequate lighting as more important.

q17.value: OLS and Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART); See PAP for details on estimation.

q27.value: Morsel Research and Development, Lucknow, India

attributes.title: Partisanship and Support for Democracy – NORC Study

q1.value: Partisanship and Support for Democracy – NORC Study

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This study replicates a portion of the study described in pre-registration #20190810AA, “Partisanship and Support for Democracy – Lucid Study.” The basic design is: randomly prime people to have a stronger partisan identity, then see if it increases their support for co-partisan candidates who have committed actions that undermine electoral fairness.

q16.value: The key hypotheses are: • Manipulation check: Priming partisan identity has a positive effect on a five-item scale designed to measure partisan identity. To test this, I will conduct a one-sided test for a positive coefficient. • Party identity increases support for co-partisans who undermine electoral fairness: In a candidate choice setup, priming respondents to have a stronger partisan identity will increase support for co-partisans who undermine electoral fairness. To test this, I will conduct a one-sided test for a positive coefficient.

q17.value: • Each hypothesis will be tested using OLS regression with standard errors clustered at the respondent level. • Each hypothesis will be tested (1) with and without pure independents in the sample and (2) including and excluding respondents who fail an attention check.

registration_responses.q1: Partisanship and Support for Democracy – NORC Study
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: This study replicates a portion of the study described in pre-registration #20190810AA, “Partisanship and Support for Democracy – Lucid Study.” The basic design is: randomly prime people to have a stronger partisan identity, then see if it increases their support for co-partisan candidates who have committed actions that undermine electoral fairness.

To test this, I will conduct a one-sided test for a positive coefficient. • Party identity increases support for co-partisans who undermine electoral fairness: In a candidate choice setup, priming respondents to have a stronger partisan identity will increase support for co-partisans who undermine electoral fairness. To test this, I will conduct a one-sided test for a positive coefficient.

attributes.title: Attitudes and Action in Refugee Policy: Evidence from Australia

q1.value: Attitudes and Action in Refugee Policy: Evidence from Australia

q5.value: The authors gratefully acknowledge financial support from the School of Politics and International Relations, and the Department of International Relations at the Australian National University.

q8.value: Registration after researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The purpose of this survey is to examine whether framing the debate about refugees who arrive in Australia by boat in different ways affects: (1) peoples’ approval of Australia’s current policies; and (2) peoples’ expressed willingness to engage in political action to change existing policies.

q16.value: Our approach involves using similar underlying logics but framing the policies as breaching international law, violating moral standards, or tarnishing Australia’s reputation. The hypotheses to be tested are whether these different frames affect (1) and/or (2) above.

q17.value: We conduct a survey experiment, working with Ipsos Australia. Respondents are divided into four groups: control, international law, moral, and reputational. The control group receives no additional information; each other group receives a very short vignette emphasizing international legal breach, moral considerations, or reputational concerns. We then ask respondents whether they approve of existing policy, and whether they would engage in the following activities with the goal of changing policy: sign a petition, attend a protest, donate to an NGO.

q29.value: The survey firm, Ipsos, received remuneration. The researchers (Sheppard and von Stein) did not.
